g.title: cluster_0
g.text: Policy goals

g.title: cluster_1
g.text: Policy instruments

g.title: Public policies
g.text: Public policies
Public policies are efforts made by governments to alter
aspects of their own or social behaviour in order to carry
out some end or purpose and are comprised of complex
arrangements of policy goals and policy means. (based on
Howlett: https://www.sfu.ca/~howlett/documents/chapter%209.M
H%20copy.pdf). We focus on policies with the purpose of
reducing emissions and/or energy use and fossil intensity.

g.title: Policy goals
g.text: Policy goals
Policy goals are a public policy wherein governments
determine operationalizable policy objectives including
specific policy targets. The aim of these goals is to guide
decision-making. (See in Howlett)

g.title: Policy instruments
g.text: Policy instruments
Policy instruments are specific policy tools by which the
government aims to achieve its objectives (based on Howlett)

g.title: Target
g.text: Target
A target is a policy goal that contains statements about a
desired future state of a system that an
organization/association/municipality/region/country commits
to in either a legally binding or non-legally binding way
(OEO, adapted)

g.title: Binding target
g.text: Binding target
A binding target is a target that is legally enforceable.
(adjusted from CPDB)

g.title: Non-binding target
g.text: Non-binding target
A non-binding is a target that is not legally enforceable.
(adjusted from CPDB)

g.title: Sectoral target
g.text: Sectoral target
A sectoral target is a target for a specific sector (own
addition).

g.title: Economy-wide target
g.text: Economy-wide target
An economy-wide target is a target for a whole economy
(adapted from CPDB)

g.title: Technology adoption target
g.text: Technology adoption target
An adoption target is a target for the adoption of a
specific energy technology within a defined timeframe.
Example: renewable energy, nuclear adoption, etc. (OWN
ADDITION)

g.title: Energy efficiency target
g.text: Energy efficiency target
A energy efficiency target is a target for efficient energy
use within a defined timeframe (adapted from CPDB)

g.title: Climate target
g.text: Climate target
A climate target is a target for GHG emission reduction
within a defined timeframe. Example: NDC commitment, net-
zero GHG emission, and climate-neutrality targets (adapted
from CPDB)

g.title: Information instrument
g.text: Information instrument
An information instrument is a policy instrument that aims
at providing knowledge to persons and/or institutions. (OEO;
equivalent to CPR Information / Hood Nodality; CPDB
"Information provision"; in Vedung "A
fundamental policy instrument involving measures undertaken
to influence addressees through the transfer of knowledge,
communication of reasoned argument, persuasion, advice"
(Public Policy and Program evaluation, p. 300)

g.title: Economic
g.text: Economic
An economic instrument is a policy instrument that hands out
or takes away material resources while the addressees are
not obligated to take the measures involved (Vedung).

g.title: Regulatory
g.text: Regulatory
A regulatory instrument is a policy instrument that is a
measure taken by governments which mandate recievers to act
in accordance with what is ordered in formulated rules and
directives (Vedung, but slightly tweaked). Such rules
prescribe the abandonment or adoption of desired processes,
technologies, products or results. Failure to comply may
incur financial penalties and/or legal sanctions (adapted
from IPCC)

g.title: Voluntary instrument
g.text: Voluntary instrument
A policy instrument where government acts in a coordinating
role, but not as a central designer and implementer of
policies; measures may be initiated by governments, but also
non-state actors such as firms or NGOs (IPCC 2018, see
especially p. 95).

g.title: Public information campaigns
g.text: Public information campaigns
Public information campaigns are an information instrument
where governments direct and sponsor efforts to communicate
information to large numbers of citizens (in Bemelmans-
Vedec, Rist and Vedung, p. 12). (own addition). Example: The
Irish government published advertisements across media
platforms to encourage energy savings and provide advice on
energy-saving measures.
https://www.iea.org/policies/15459-a-nationwide-campaign-to-
encourage-energy-efficiency-and-highlight-available-supports

g.title: Education instrument
g.text: Education instrument
An education instrument is an information policy instrument
that aims at teaching skills to specific groups of people
(OEO). [NOTE: merged categories, sub-category of
Information]

g.title: Implementation aid
g.text: Implementation aid
Implementation aid is an educational policy instrument that
provides assistance to actors engaging in desired activities
(CPDB, slightly modified to fit OEO terminology & put
within new subcategory of information "education
instrument"). Example: experts employed by the German
government provide advice on building efficiency
("Energieberatung": https://www.energiewechsel.de/
KAENEF/Redaktion/DE/Dossier/energieberatung-uebersicht.html)

g.title: Changes to public education
g.text: Changes to public education
Changes to public education are an education policy
instrument which changes what is taught in public schooling
to focus on promoting desired behavior. Example: curricula
and learning objectives focused on climate change, see :
https://unesdoc.unesco.org/ark:/48223/pf0000379591

g.title: Training program
g.text: Training program
A training program is an educational policy instrument that
promotes learning for professionals to obtain, improve or
retain skills, knowledge, tools, equipment or other
resources to do their work competently (adapted from CPDB,
professional training and qualification; part of definition
from EEA: https://climate-
adapt.eea.europa.eu/en/metadata/adaptation-options/capacity-
building-on-climate-change-adaptation)

g.title: Vocational training
g.text: Vocational training
Vocational training is a training program that prepares
people with specific skills for technical or trades work
(own definintion). Example:
https://www.iea.org/policies/17844-cooperative-training-at-
coal-sites-in-north-rhine-westphalia

g.title: Levy
g.text: Levy
A levy is an economic instrument that consists of a
compulsory financial charge imposed on an agent or
institution by a governmental organisation. [OEO]

g.title: Financial incentive
g.text: Financial incentive
a financial incentive is an economic policy instruments used
by the state to encourage targeted products or activities by
providing economic support to selected actors. Beneficiaries
typically receive this support through mechanisms such as
soft loans, grants, market premiums, and tax reductions (own
definition)

g.title: Direct investment
g.text: Direct investment
a direct investment is an economic policy instrument in
which the government supports targeted activities or
products by directly purchasing, investing in, or producing
them through public agencies, institutions or utlities.

g.title: Trading scheme
g.text: Trading scheme
A trading scheme is an economic policy instrument an
economic policy instrument in which a standard is set for
environmental performance, and then performance certificates
or credits can be traded in a marketplace to incentivize or
discourage targeted activities (own definition, gathered
from CPDB definitions of sub-instrument types)

g.title: Tax
g.text: Tax
A tax is a levy imposed by the government that is not tied
to a specific benefit or service.

g.title: Fee / charge
g.text: Fee / charge
A fee or charge is a levy imposed by the government in
exchange for providing a specific good or service.

g.title: Carbon & GHG Taxes
g.text: Carbon & GHG Taxes
A carbon tax is a tax on carbon or other greenhouse gas
emissions, measured in CO2 equivalent values (combination of
OEO and CPDB definition; CPDB, slightly tweaked to include
OEO terminology)

g.title: Energy tax
g.text: Energy tax
An energy tax is a charge imposed on the production, sale,
or consumption of energy sources, including fuels and
electricity, typically calculated based on the quantity or
type of energy used. (CPDB changed to seperate 'other
taxes')

g.title: Increased charges
g.text: Increased charges
An increased charge is a levy imposed by the government on
certain undesireable goods or behaviors. Example: higher
vehicle registration fees for high-emissions vehicles
(adapted from "user charges", CPDB)

g.title: Feebate (Bonus/Malus)
g.text: Feebate (Bonus/Malus)
A feebate is an economic instrument that combines a fee and
a rebate system to influence behavior. Actors whose
activities exceed a defined threshold (e.g. high emissions
or low efficiency) pay a surcharge ("malus"),
while those who perform better than the threshold receive a
financial reward ("bonus"). The scheme is
typically designed to be revenue-neutral. See:
https://academic.oup.com/ej/article-
abstract/124/578/F444/5076980, https://www.tandfonline.com/d

g.title: Fee Reductions & Exemptions
g.text: Fee Reductions &
Exemptions
Fee decreases and exemptions are financial incentives where
the government supports targeted activities by reducing or
exempting them from existing fees or charges. Example: the
German 9 Euro ticket to promote using public transport, or
the removal of vehicle registration fees for electric
vehicles. (OWN ADDITION, based on CPDB user charge)

g.title: Fossil Fuel Subsidy Removal
g.text: Fossil Fuel Subsidy Removal
removal of fossil fuel subsidies is a financial incentive
which abolishes or reduces existing subsidies for fossil
fuels, either at the production or consumption ends (CPDB,
moved from Section "Barrier removal", slightly
tweaked for OEO)

g.title: Tax incentive
g.text: Tax incentive
A tax incentive is a fiscal incentive where the government
reduces or exempts selected activities, goods or actors from
taxes (CPDB)

g.title: Retirement premium
g.text: Retirement premium
A retirement premium is a fiscal incentive where the
government provides support for the early retirement of
emissions-intensive or inefficient assets (CPDB, moved from
Section "Economic-Fiscal and Financial Incentives"
and tweaked slightly for OEO)

g.title: Market premium
g.text: Market premium
A market premium is a fiscal incentive that ensures
additional remuneration on top of market prices, or a
guaranteed renumeration by paying to the producing agent the
difference between a guaranteed return on a product and the
monetary price for which the product is traded on the
market.

g.title: Grant
g.text: Grant
a grant is fiscal incentive where the government provides
non-repayable funding for specific purposes (CPDB, split
from "grants and subsidies" into
"grants" and "subsidies", slightly
modified to fit OEO terminology)

g.title: Loans and insurances
g.text: Loans and insurances
Loans and insurances are financial incentives where the
government provides repayable funding or offers guarantees
and insurance schemes to reduce risk and facilitate access
to financing for specific purposes.

g.title: Tax reduction
g.text: Tax reduction
A tax reduction is a tax incentive where the government
reduces taxes for selected activities, goods or actors
(CPDB, moved from Section "Fiscal and Financial
incentives" and split in to reduction and exemption)

g.title: Accelerated depreciation rule
g.text: Accelerated depreciation rule
Accelerated depreciation rule is a tax rebate where the
government allows sustainable projects to depreciate (part
of) the investment in the early years of the asset's
life, effectively reducing their taxable income during these
years (Hafner & Lilliestam 2019, tweaked for OEO and
moved)

g.title: Tax rebate
g.text: Tax rebate
A tax rebate is a tax reduction on a purchase (Own addition,
definition via
https://www.cleanenergyresourceteams.org/what-you-need-know-
about-ira-tax-credit-vs-rebate)

g.title: Tax credit
g.text: Tax credit
A tax credit is a tax reduction on income taxes that would
otherwise be owed. (Own addition, definition via
https://www.cleanenergyresourceteams.org/what-you-need-know-
about-ira-tax-credit-vs-rebate)

g.title: Product retirement premium
g.text: Product retirement premium
a retirement premium for emissions-intensive products used
by consumers such as fossil fuel vehicle swap or scrappage
schemes (own addition, in conversation with CPDB)

g.title: Asset retirement premium
g.text: Asset retirement premium
an asset retirement premium is a premium for the early
closure of certain assets. Example: payments for early
closure of coal-fired power plants (own addition, in
conversation with CPDB)

g.title: Capacity premium
g.text: Capacity premium
A capacity premium is a market premium that guarantees
remuneration for reserving electric capacity to be available
for unexpected events (OEO). Example: payments for large-
scale battery installations.

g.title: Feed-in Premium
g.text: Feed-in Premium
A feed-in premium is a market premium where energy
generators are paid a premium on top of the price they
achieve in the electricity market, for electricity fed into
the grid for a number of years in the future (Lilliestam
definition)

g.title: Feed-in Tariff
g.text: Feed-in Tariff
A feed-in tariff is a market premium where energy producers
are paid fixed prices for every unit of energy fed into the
grid for a number of years in the future (Lilliestam
definition; different from OEO; and differs from CPDB:
"Renewable electricity price surcharge to benefit
producers")

g.title: Auction with market premium
g.text: Auction with market premium
An auction with a market premium is a market premium granted
in a bidding competition or auction, wherein tendered
capacity includes additional support through a mechanism
such as a FITs, FIP or CfD (edited to fit OEO typology, from
Hafner & Lilliestam 2019)

g.title: Fixed FIP
g.text: Fixed FIP
A fixed FIP is a FIP where producers receive a fixed amount
of excess revenue on top of the market price (own addition,
definition via https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-
content/EN/TXT/HTML/?uri=CELEX:52022DC0638)22DC0638)

g.title: Floating/Sliding Premium
g.text: Floating/Sliding Premium
A floating premium is a feed-in premium with a variable
subsidy which complements the market price (own addition,
definition via https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-
content/EN/TXT/HTML/?uri=CELEX:52022DC0638; https://www.scie
ncedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0140988316302377#fn0030)

g.title: Contract for Difference
g.text: Contract for Difference
A contract for difference is a feed-in premium wherein a
public entity concludes a contract to encourage investment.
It tops up the market price paid for electricity if the
price is below a certain level, but requires the generator
to pay back amounts where the market price is above a
certain level. https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/d
etail/en/qanda_23_1593. In the case of the UK, this is
between electricity generators and a government-owned
company https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/contracts-
for-difference .

g.title: Two-sided Contract for Difference
g.text: Two-sided Contract for
Difference
A two-sided contract for difference is a feed-in premium
wherein a public entity (typically the state) concludes a
contract with an electricity generator, which sets a strike
price. The generator sells the electricity in the market but
then settles with the public entity the difference between
the market price and the strike price. It thus allows the
generator to receive a stable revenue for the electricity it
produces, while at the same time it provides a revenue
limitation for generators when market prices are high. In a
two-way CfD, if the market price is below the strike price,
the generator receives the difference; if the market price
is above the strike price, the generator pays back the
difference.. https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/det
ail/en/qanda_23_1593

g.title: FIP with Floor Price
g.text: FIP with Floor Price
A FIP with floor price is a floating premium where, if
market price is below the targeted subsidy, producers
receive support that covers the gap, and if market price is
higher, they can keep the excess revenue (own addition,
definition via https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-
content/EN/TXT/HTML/?uri=CELEX:52022DC0638)

g.title: Symmetrical Premium
g.text: Symmetrical Premium
A 2-sided premium is a floating premium which has both a
floor and ceiling price whereby positive and negative
deviations are paid out to the contractual partner. This
means that a minimum compensation is guaranteed, but
revenues are capped. (own addition; definition via
https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-
content/EN/TXT/HTML/?uri=CELEX:52022DC0638)

g.title: Purchase grant
g.text: Purchase grant
A purchase grant is a grant to support the acquisition of
specific products. It reduces the upfront cost for buyers,
making the targeted product more affordable and attractive.

g.title: R&D grant
g.text: R&D grant
An R&D grant is a grant to support research and
development. (own addition; equivalent to CPDB "R&D
funding", according to their codebook)

g.title: Soft loan
g.text: Soft loan
A soft loan is an economic policy instrument where the
government provides loans for at preferential conditions to
lower financing costs. (Example: low-interest loan for a
company to build charging infrastructure, or for a person to
purchase an EV). (Hafner & Lilliestam 2019, tweaked to
include different kinds of financing)

g.title: Loan guarantee
g.text: Loan guarantee
A loan guarantee is an economic policy instrument where the
government guarantees to pay the loan should the project go
bankrupt, lowering the default risk and therefore the
required returns on debt and/or equity (Hafner &
Lilliestam 2019, tweaked for OEO)

g.title: Insurance
g.text: Insurance
An insurance mechanism is a fiscal/financial investment
where the government provides insurance to projects (CPR,
from section Economic:Incentives and direct investment and
tweaked slightly for OEO definitions)

g.title: Direct asset investment
g.text: Direct asset investment
direct asset investment is a direct investment by the
government in assets. Example: purchasing stakes in a firm,
purchasing a power plant, constructing and operating
infrastructures (own addition)

g.title: Direct R&D funding
g.text: Direct R&D funding
R&D funding is a direct investment by the government in
public research institutions or projects (CPDB - relocated
and tweaked for OEO)

g.title: Green public procurement
g.text: Green public procurement
government purchases a green good or service directly.
Example: power purchase agreements if the offtaker is a
state entity; purchase of a fleet of electric buses by a
city for public transit. (tweaked/combined CPR "green
procurement", CPDB "procurement rules").

g.title: Direct infrastructure investment
g.text: Direct infrastructure
investment
direct infrastructure investment is a direct investment by
the government in infrastructure projects (CPDB, tweaked
slightly)

g.title: Direct power generation investment
g.text: Direct power generation
investment
direct power generation investment is an investment by the
government in power generation capacity (own addition).

g.title: Direct asset investment->Direct power generation investment
GHG Emissions Trading
g.text: GHG Emissions Trading
An greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme is a trading
scheme wherein governments issue tradable emissions
certificates, often combined with a fixed emissions cap
(overall or set on specific actors), thereby setting
economic incentives to reduce emissions (CPDB, tweaked a
bit)

g.title: White certificate trading scheme
g.text: White certificate trading
scheme
A white certificate scheme is a trading scheme where the
government has established a quota for the generation of
tradable energy savings certificates produced by energy
efficiency activities OR reduced energy consumption measured
against a baseline; these can be traded to incentivize
emissions reducations (CPDB, tweaked to conform with other
definitions and to include Chinese energy consumption
trading scheme)

g.title: Green certificate trading scheme
g.text: Green certificate trading
scheme
a green certificate scheme is a trading scheme where
producers of renewable electricity receive tradable
certificates for each unit of electricity generated. These
certificates can then be sold separately from the
electricity itself, typically to energy suppliers who are
obligated via a quota to source a certain share of their
electricity from renewables. This creates a market for
certificates, providing a financial incentive for renewable
energy investment and production (CPDB)

g.title: Offsetting scheme
g.text: Offsetting scheme
An offsetting scheme is a trading scheme where mitigation
activities can calculate their impact against a baseline to
obtain credits which can be sold for offsetting purposes
such as Baseline-and-Credit schemes (CPDB, slightly changed
following discussion). This differs from an emissions
trading scheme in that it does not have a cap, and can avoid
emissions rather than reducing them. Example: Clean
Development Mechanism.

g.title: Zoning & Spatial Planning
g.text: Zoning & Spatial Planning
A zoning and spatial planning regulation is a policy
instrument that determines where objects can exist in space:
either where something can be built/used, or what kinds of
things can be built in specific geographic locations (Own
definition; exists in CPR but without subcategories).

g.title: Standard
g.text: Standard
A standard is a regulatory policy instrument that defines
requirements for products, production processes, services or
test-methods (EU, on European standards - https://single-
market-economy.ec.europa.eu/single-market/european-
standards_en )

g.title: Market design regulation
g.text: Market design regulation
Market design regulation is a regulatory policy instrument
that sets out the permitted roles and interaction procedures
for market actors, including who can participate and how
prices are determined [own addition and definition].

g.title: Institutional creation
g.text: Institutional creation
Institutional creation is a regulatory policy instrument
creating institutions. Example: creation of a new government
agency or body (CPDB, moved from section "Policy
Support" and tweaked slightly) / similar to
"Institutional Mandates" in CPR)

g.title: Location regulation
g.text: Location regulation
A location regulation is a zoning and spatial planning
instrument that determines where objects or related
infrastructure can be built or used (OWN ADDITION).

g.title: Characteristic regulation
g.text: Characteristic regulation
A characteristic regulation is a zoning and spatial planning
instrument that determines what kinds of objects or related
insfrastructure can be built or used in specific locations
(OWN ADDITION).

g.title: Setback distance
g.text: Setback distance
A setback distance is a zoning and spatial planning
instrument that sets a minimum distance between objects.
Example: the distances between a wind turbine and a
residential building, railroads, transmission line, and
bodies of water (Own addition, see
https://www.nrel.gov/news/program/2022/nrel-releases-
comprehensive-databases-of-local-ordinances-for-siting-wind-
solar-energy-projects.html )

g.title: Exclusion area
g.text: Exclusion area
An exclusion area is a zoning and spatial planning
regulation that excludes a certain area from being eligible
for objects to be built or entered. Example: an exclusion
zone where wind turbines may not be built due to legal,
environmental or safety concerns. (own addition and
definition & adapted from Bucha and Ramirez Camargo,
"Deliverable D2.10 Data on Regulatory and Socio-
Economic Conditions and Impacts (b).". Dec. 2024.)

g.title: Priority area
g.text: Priority area
A priority area is a zoning and spatial planning regulation
that prioritizes a certain area to be built or entered, and
within this zone, the other activities are mainly not
allowed. Example: a priority zone for wind energy due to the
high wind potential or less conflict with neighborhoods.
(OWN ADDITION and adapted from Bucha and Ramirez Camargo,
"Deliverable D2.10 Data on Regulatory and Socio-
Economic Conditions and Impacts (b).". Dec. 2024.)

g.title: Low emissions zone
g.text: Low emissions zone
A low emissions zone is an exclusion area where vehicles
with higher emissions cannot enter (Own addition, see EU
urban access regulations:
https://urbanaccessregulations.eu/low-emission-zones-main)

g.title: Area limitation
g.text: Area limitation
An area limitation is a zoning and spatial planning
regulation that limits the area in which objects can be
built. Example: roof area limitation for installing rooftop
PV (OWN ADDITION).

g.title: Noise limit
g.text: Noise limit
A noise limit is a zoning and spatial planning regulation
that sets a noise limit in a specific area. Example: noise
limits for wind turbines in residential areas. (OWN ADDITION
and adapted from Bucha and Ramirez Camargo,
"Deliverable D2.10 Data on Regulatory and Socio-
Economic Conditions and Impacts (b).". Dec. 2024.)

g.title: Shadow flicker limit
g.text: Shadow flicker limit
A shadow flicker limit is a zoning and spatial planning
regulation that sets a shadow flicker limit (OWN ADDITION)

g.title: Height restriction
g.text: Height restriction
A maximum height regulation is a zoning and spatial planning
instrument that sets a maximum height for an object. An
example includes a height limitation of wind turbine (Own
addition)

g.title: Rotor size restriction
g.text: Rotor size restriction
A rotor size restriction is a zoning and spatial planning
instrument that sets a rotor restriction for an object.
Example: a rotor size limitation of wind turbine (Own
addition, used in NREL data)

g.title: Installed capacity limitation
g.text: Installed capacity limitation
An installed capacity limitation is a zoning and spatial
planning instrument that limits the installed capacity of a
particular object, or renewable generation site. Example: an
installed capacity limitation for rooftop PV (OWN ADDITION).

g.title: Performance standard
g.text: Performance standard
A performance standard is a standard that sets required
levels of performance (in terms of emissions, efficiency
etc), but actors are free to choose the technologies and
methods for how they will do so. (IPCC, tweaked for OEO)

g.title: Technology standard
g.text: Technology standard
A technology standard is a standard that requires a specific
technology, process or product. They typically take one of
four forms: requirements for specific pollution abatement
technologies; requirements for specific production methods;
requirements for specific goods such as energy efficient
appliances; or phase-out mandates (IPCC)

g.title: Quota
g.text: Quota
A quota is a standard wherein a quantified obligation is
imposed on some actor to acquire, use, install etc. a
certain quota of a clean good or service. These may or may
not be tied to trading schemes like green or white
certificates schemes. These may be either technology or
performance standards. Example: minimum shares of zero-
emission vehicles or of renewable electricity. (adapted from
European Commission, Bertoldi and Rezessy 2006, https://publ
ications.jrc.ec.europa.eu/repository/bitstream/JRC32865/2865
-white_cert_report_final.pdf).

g.title: Public sector mandate
g.text: Public sector mandate
A public sector mandate is a standard which requires public
bodies decision-making to align with government targets.
Example: all ministry actions must comply with carbon budget
ceilings.
https://www.lse.ac.uk/granthaminstitute/publication/impacts-
of-climate-framework-laws/

g.title: Public procurement standards
g.text: Public procurement standards
a standard set by governments for public goods. These can be
technology-specific or performance-based. Example:
government standard that any vehicles purchased by public
actors must meet certain emissions threshholds (own
addition).

g.title: Tendering/Auction Standards
g.text: Tendering/Auction Standards
A tendering scheme standard is the standards set for bidding
competition for potential providers of a required good or
service aimed at reducing provision costs, e.g., through
auctions. This can be tied to economic policy instruments
such as FITs. The standards may be technology-specific or
performance-based. Example: a solar PV auction, or an
auction for low-emissions hydrogen (CPDB, moved from section
"Economic-Fiscal and Financial incentives",
tweaked slightly for OEO)

g.title: Offsetting rules
g.text: Offsetting rules
offsetting rules are standards which establish GHG emission
reductions crediting and offsetting regulations (CPDB, split
between this definition and market above). Example: rules
that prohibit using offsetting as part of emissions
calculations.

g.title: Disclosure Standard
g.text: Disclosure Standard
Disclosure standards are standards that require an actor to
publicly disclose and substantiate claims on environmental
impacts (own definition; exists in CPR, but we have moved it
to sub-section "standards" whereas it is stand-
alone in CPR)

g.title: Due diligence obligation
g.text: Due diligence obligation
A due diligence obligation is a standard requiring companies
to identify and address potential and actual adverse impacts
in a company's operations. Example: French
"corporate vigilance" law

g.title: Emissions Cap/Standard
g.text: Emissions Cap/Standard
a performance standard that sets a cap on emissions or
pollution, either total per actor/sector, or per unit of
output (see https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pi

g.title: Energy Use/Efficiency Standard
g.text: Energy Use/Efficiency Standard
a performance standard that sets a cap on energy use, either
total per actor/sector, or per unit of output (own addition)

g.title: Sectoral emissions cap
g.text: Sectoral emissions cap
A sectoral emissions cap is a cap that sets out the maximum
amount for how much actors are allowed to emit or pollute
(OWN addition. May be a regulatory element of a trading
system; see https://climate.ec.europa.eu/eu-action/eu-
emissions-trading-system-eu-ets/emissions-cap-and-
allowances_en )

g.title: Industrial air pollution standard
g.text: Industrial air pollution
standard
An industrial air pollution standard is a mandatory standard
for the emission of polluting substances by industry actors
including but not limited to GHG gases (CPDB, tweaked for
OEO)

g.title: Building emissions standard
g.text: Building emissions standard
standards that regulate the allowable levels of pollution or
CO2 emissions associated with the building (such as heating
systems).

g.title: Product emissions standard
g.text: Product emissions standard
A product emissions standard is an emissions standard for
specific products to limit their emissions/pollution (CPDB -
"product standard" refers only to appliances;
split into 2, this one and "product efficiency
standard")

g.title: Vehicle air pollution or emissions standard
g.text: Vehicle air pollution or
emissions standard
A vehicle air pollution standard is a product emissions
standards for vehicles, for the maximum emission of
substances such as greenhouse gas emissions, hydrocarbons,
oxides of nitrogen and particulate matter they can emit
(CPDB, tweaked for OEO) --> NOTE: changed scope, included
GHG emissions

g.title: Product emissions standard->Vehicle air pollution or emissions standard
Fuel air pollution or emissions standard
g.text: Fuel air pollution or
emissions standard
a fuel standard is a product emissions standard that sets
out emissions and pollution requirements for fuel (own
addition, see https://climate.ec.europa.eu/eu-
action/transport/fuel-quality_en). NOTE: some policy
instruments called "fuel standard" are a
combination of a performance standard and an emissions
trading system (like Canada's LCFS - see https://www.sc
iencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0301421523005049).

g.title: Product emissions standard->Fuel air pollution or emissions standard
Sectoral energy use cap
g.text: Sectoral energy use cap
a sectoral energy use cap is an energy use cap that sets the
maximum amount for how much energy actors in a certain
sector are allowed to consume. This can be (but is not
always) a regulatory element of efficiency-related trading
systems (OWN addition, see https://www.sciencedirect.com/sci
ence/article/pii/S0360544221022192)

g.title: Energy Use/Efficiency Standard->Sectoral energy use cap
Energy efficiency quota
g.text: Energy efficiency quota
An efficiency quota is an energy cap that sets out quotas
for energy efficiency improvements (based on CPDB
"Obligation Scheme" but differentiated)

g.title: Industrial efficiency standard
g.text: Industrial efficiency standard
An industrial efficiency standard is a mandatory standard
for the energy efficiency of industry actors (CPDB, tweaked
for OEO)

g.title: Building efficiency standard
g.text: Building efficiency standard
a building efficiency standard is a building standard which
requires buildings to comply with requirements for energy
demand and the heat that can escape. Example: standards for
insulation. (OWN DEFINITION).

g.title: Product efficiency standard
g.text: Product efficiency standard
A product efficiency standard is an efficiency standard for
specific products to limit their energy intensity (CPDB -
"product standard" refers only to appliances;
split into 2, this one and "product emissions
standard")

g.title: Vehicle fuel-economy or efficiency standard
g.text: Vehicle fuel-economy or
efficiency standard
A vehicle fuel-economy/efficiency standard is a product
standard for vehicles that determines a minimum fuel-
efficiency threshhold (CPDB, tweaked for OEO; note: removed
emissions, shifted to child of procuct standard, no longer
CPDB compatible)

g.title: Product efficiency standard->Vehicle fuel-economy or efficiency standard
Moratoria or ban
g.text: Moratoria or ban
A moratoria or ban is a technology standard that forbids an
activity, technology or product because of its environmental
harms (CPR - NOTE: this is moved to sub-section
'standards', whereas it is stand-alone in CPR)

g.title: Purchasing requirement / quota
g.text: Purchasing requirement / quota
(demand-side quota): A purchasing requirement/quota is a
quota which requires an actor to acquire a certain share of
a clean good or service. (adapted from European Commission,
Bertoldi and Rezessy 2006, https://publications.jrc.ec.europ
a.eu/repository/bitstream/JRC32865/2865-
white_cert_report_final.pdf). Examples: a minimum share of
zero-emission vehicles or of renewable electricity [also
known as: portfolio standard, purchase obligation].

g.title: Production requirement / quota
g.text: Production requirement / quota
(supply-side quota): A production requirement/quota is a
quota which requires an actor to provide a certain share of
a clean good or service. Example: China's supply-side
renewables portfolio standards, see https://www.sciencedirec
t.com/science/article/pii/S030142152300383X?via%3Dihub#abs00

g.title: Installation requirement / quota
g.text: Installation requirement /
quota
An installation requirement is a quota which requires an
actor to install a certain share of a clean good or service.
Example: parking lot owner must install at least 1 EV
charger per 10 parking spaces; 100% of new rented buildings
must have solar panels.

g.title: Smart meter installation requirement
g.text: Smart meter installation
requirement
A smart meter installation requirement is a technology-
specific installation requirement that mandates the
installation of smart meters (Own addition: see
https://www.smart-energy.com/regional-news/europe-
uk/germany-mandates-smart-metering-from-2025)

g.title: Installation requirement / quota->Smart meter installation requirement
PV installation requirement
g.text: PV installation requirement
A PV installation requirement is a is a technology-specific
installation requirement that sets requirements for
installing solar PV systems. Example: PV panels must be
installed on new buildings, renovated roofs, or parking
garages (OWN ADDITION)

g.title: EV charging installation requirement
g.text: EV charging installation
requirement
An EV charging installation requirement is a is a
technology-specific installation requirement that sets
requirements for installing EV charging stations. Example: 1
in 10 parking spaces must include EV charging stations (OWN
ADDITION)

g.title: Installation requirement / quota->EV charging installation requirement
Storage installation requirement
g.text: Storage installation
requirement
A storage installation requirement is an installation
requirement that sets requirements for actors to install
energy storage capacities. Example: a person who installs a
solar PV system must also install a battery storage unit.
(OWN ADDITION)

g.title: Comparison label standard
g.text: Comparison label standard
A comparison label standard is a disclosure standard which
requires participation in consumer-oriented labelling
schemes. These schemes provide a rating of a certain good or
service against a pre-determined scale, allowing for a
comparison across products (CPDB (originally in information
and education category), moved into subcategory disclosure
obligations and tweaked for OEO). Example: labeling
standards for building energy efficiency

g.title: Financial disclosure standard
g.text: Financial disclosure standard
A financial disclosure standard is a disclosure standard
which requires companies to disclose how the transition
risks from shifting to a low-carbon economy and physical
climate change impacts may affect their business or asset
values. Example: EU SFDR. (own addition via IPCC 2022 but
slightly tweaked).

g.title: Supply chain disclosure standard
g.text: Supply chain disclosure
standard
A supply chain disclosure standard is a disclosure standard
that requires firms to disclose information on the risks and
opportunities arising from environmental issues, and on the
impact of their activities the environment. Example: EU
CSRD. (own addition via EU)

g.title: Green advertisement standards
g.text: Green advertisement standards
Green advertisement standards are disclosure standards on
companies that make claims about their environmental impact
to adhere to standards which may include disclosing their
assessment methodology, verification by an independent third
party, and greenhouse gas offsetting (own definition).
Example: EU Green Claims Directive
https://environment.ec.europa.eu/topics/circular-
economy/green-claims_en

g.title: Supply chain due diligence obligations
g.text: Supply chain due diligence
obligations
Supply chain due diligence obligations are due diligence
obligations for companies to address risks not only their
own operations, but also their subsidiaries and business
partners. Example: the EU Corporate sustainability due
diligence directive (CSDDD), https://www.csr-in-
deutschland.de/EN/Business-Human-Rights/Supply-Chain-
Act/supply-chain-act.html and
https://commission.europa.eu/business-economy-euro/doing-
business-eu/sustainability-due-diligence-responsible-
business/corporate-sustainability-due-diligence_en

g.title: Due diligence obligation->Supply chain due diligence obligations
Grid access and priority for renewables
g.text: Grid access and priority for
renewables
Grid access and priority for renewables is a market design
regulation that gives priority to renewable energy
production and guarantees full purchase of their electricity
(CPDB, moved from Section "Barrier removal")

g.title: Market design regulation->Grid access and priority for renewables
Rule on integrating controllable devices
g.text: Rule on integrating
controllable devices
A rule on integrating controllable devices is a market
design regulation for the interactions between grid
operators and controllable consumer devices. Example: grid
operators cannot refuse connection of a heat pump, but they
may be allowed to switch off the device if there is an acute
threat of overloading their networks. (Own addition - see h
ttps://www.bundesnetzagentur.de/SharedDocs/Pressemitteilunge

g.title: Market design regulation->Rule on integrating controllable devices
Rules on dynamic pricing
g.text: Rules on dynamic pricing
Rules on dynamic pricing is a market design regulation which
allows for dynamic pricing, setting electricity prices for
consumers to reflect the price variation at the spot
markets. (Own addition)
https://www.ceer.eu/publication/ceer-recommendations-on-
dynamic-price-implementation/

g.title: Market design regulation->Rules on dynamic pricing
Independent power production policy
g.text: Independent power production
policy
an independent power production policy is a market design
regulation which allows non-governmental actors to generate
electricity. (Own addition)

g.title: Market design regulation->Independent power production policy
Direct purchasing regulation (PPA)
g.text: Direct purchasing regulation
(PPA)
Direct purchasing regulation is a market design regulation
that allows independent power producers to sell electricity
to others actors. This implies a bilateral contract between
an electricity producer (often a renewable energy developer)
and a buyer. Example: A company sells electricity directly
to a data center, rather than to a utility (own addition;
see https://www.clarke-energy.com/applications/independent-
power-producers/ )

g.title: Self-consumption policy
g.text: Self-consumption policy
A self-consumption policy is a market design regulation
which allows individuals to produce and consume their own
power.

g.title: Net metering / net billing policy
g.text: Net metering / net billing
policy
A net metering policy is a market design regulation which
allows consumers who generate their own electricity to also
buy and sell electricity from the grid. See for example: htt
ps://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S096014811930

g.title: Market design regulation->Net metering / net billing policy
Citizen financial participation
g.text: Citizen financial
participation
Citizen financial participation is a market design
regulation which allows residents and communities to become
partial owners of energy assets (OWN ADDITION). Example: htt
ps://www.researchgate.net/publication/371389707_Prufung_eine
r_Landesregelung_zur_finanziellen_Be-_teiligung_an_Windenerg
ieanlagen_an_Land_fur_den_Freistaat_Sachsen_Executive_Summar
y

g.title: Auditing institution
g.text: Auditing institution
An auditing institution is an institution created to enforce
compliances with established governmental rules and
standards (CPDB, moved from section "Regulatory-Codes
and standards" with slight language tweaks)

g.title: Monitoring institution
g.text: Monitoring institution
A monitoring institution is an institution created to
continuously and systematically collect of data to supervise
specific activities for evaluation and enforcement purposes
(CPDB, slightly tweaked)

g.title: Coordinating body for climate strategy
g.text: Coordinating body for climate
strategy
A coordinating body for climate strategy is an institution
created to regulate and monitor climate change responses and
strategies (from CPDB, moved from Section "Climate
Strategy" and slightly changed wording)

g.title: Institutional creation->Coordinating body for climate strategy
Independent advisory body
g.text: Independent advisory body
A Independent advisory body is an institution created to
provide evidence and analysis from which government actors
can build strategies and plans (new addition, via Kate from
CPR). Example: UK Climate Change Committee
https://www.lse.ac.uk/granthaminstitute/news/why-the-uks-
climate-change-committee-is-crucial-to-advancing-evidence-
based-climate-policymaking/

g.title: Participation scheme
g.text: Participation scheme
A participation scheme is an institution created to promote
the involvement of subnational entities or citizens in
sustainability governance (adapted from CPR, own
definition). Example: citizen climate assemblies, see
https://www.knoca.eu/climate-assemblies

g.title: Climate fund
g.text: Climate fund
A climate fund is an institution created to provide the
establishment of specific funding agencies or mechanisms for
climate issues. Example: independent domestic agencies for
climate finance
https://www.iea.org/policies/14055-government-investment-in-
decarbonising-industry-fund-gidi.

g.title: Strategic planning process
g.text: Strategic planning process
A strategic planning process is the institutionalization of
processes to set strategic direction and roadmaps for
specific sectors or for the economy as a whole (CPDB,
changed slightly on advice of CPR).

g.title: MRV of emissions
g.text: MRV of emissions
A Measurement, Reporting and Verification (MRV) monitoring
institution establishes systems for the measurement,
reporting, and verification of emissions data to ensure its
veracity, consistency and compliance with reporting
requirements (suggested by CPR; own definition based on
paraphrase of https://unece.org/monitoring-reporting-and-
verification-mrv)

g.title: Public voluntary scheme
g.text: Public voluntary scheme
A public voluntary scheme is a voluntary measure where a
regulator develops a program or performance criteria with
which industries and firms can choose whether or not to
comply. Examples: eco-labels such as the German Blue Angel,
Nordic Swan, or US Energy Star.

g.title: Public-Private Negotiated Agreement
g.text: Public-Private Negotiated
Agreement
A negotiated agreement between the public and private sector
is a voluntary measure where governments and the private
sector establish a set of targets for environmental issues
(Penasco 2021). The precise terms of the agreement vary in
terms of what information must be reported and how this is
audited, whether or not the targets are legally binding etc.
In most instances, agreements are negotiated to avoid direct
regulation or market-based instruments (Bailey 2008).

g.title: International agreement
g.text: International agreement
A negotiated international agreement is an agreement between
international actors which sets targets for environmental
issues, to which other actors can choose to commit. This
commitment and targets can be binding or not. Example: the
Powering Past Coal Alliance led by the UK and Canada, where
joining members commit to accelerating the transition from
coal to clean energy https://poweringpastcoal.org/)

g.title: Public-private partnership (PPP)
g.text: Public-private partnership
(PPP)
A Public-private partnership is a voluntary collaborative
relationship between various parties, both state and non-
state, in which all parties work together to achieve a
common purpose or specific task and share risks,
responsibilities, resources, and benefits (own addition -
the definition is from Kolati and Raghutla, 2023, originally
cited in Hodge and Greve, 2011
